text:
do I get the job if I did it in <5min?
```function runlenenc(x)
    @assert length(x) > 0 "wut wut"
    lastthing, count = first(x), 1
    lulwut = []
    (length(x) == 1) && return [(x, 1)]
    for chr in x[2:end]
        if lastthing == chr
            count += 1
        else 
            push!( lulwut, (lastthing, count) )
            count = 1
        end
        lastthing = chr
    end
    push!( lulwut, (lastthing, count) )
    return lulwut
end

runlenenc("aaaabbbcca") .|> println```

elements.text: do I get the job if I did it in <5min?

function runlenenc(x)
    @assert length(x) > 0 "wut wut"
    lastthing, count = first(x), 1
    lulwut = []
    (length(x) == 1) && return [(x, 1)]
    for chr in x[2:end]
        if lastthing == chr
            count += 1
        else 
            push!( lulwut, (lastthing, count) )
            count = 1
        end
        lastthing = chr
    end
    push!( lulwut, (lastthing, count) )
    return lulwut
end

runlenenc("aaaabbbcca") .|> println

text:
codegolf?
```s = "aaaaabbbccddda"

rle = reduce(s, init = []) do vec, char
    lchar = isempty(vec) ? nothing : vec[end][1]
    if lchar == char
        vec[end] = (char, vec[end][2] + 1)
    else
        push!(vec, (char, 1))
    end
    vec
end```

elements.text: codegolf?

s = "aaaaabbbccddda"

rle = reduce(s, init = []) do vec, char
    lchar = isempty(vec) ? nothing : vec[end][1]
    if lchar == char
        vec[end] = (char, vec[end][2] + 1)
    else
        push!(vec, (char, 1))
    end
    vec
end

text:
Julia doesn’t have one in base because no-one can decide what it should do.
There are two options.
The one Haskell and IterTools.jl follow where it is only successive groups.
The one DataFrames.jl follow where it is non-successive groups.

I suspect the resolution is to add both in a single PR.
`consecutive_groupby` and `uniquely_groupby`

elements.text:

There are two options.

The one DataFrames.jl follow where it is non-successive groups.

I suspect the resolution is to add both in a single PR.
consecutive_groupby
and
uniquely_groupby

text:
History:
Base.Iterators originally only contained the iterators that Base itself needed.
Everything else was in IterTools. Following the policy of “put it in a package if you possibly can”
but over time, Base needed more and more things.
and people kept trying to stick other things they wanted in Base.Iterators.

Maybe it is time to give that one up.

elements.text:

text:
No, DataFrames is not sequential
Data science types really strongly feel it should not be.

```julia> groupby(DataFrame(x = collect("aaabcccdda")), "x")
GroupedDataFrame with 4 groups based on key: x
First Group (4 rows): x = 'a'
 Row │ x
     │ Char
─────┼──────
   1 │ a
   2 │ a
   3 │ a
   4 │ a
⋮
Last Group (2 rows): x = 'd'
 Row │ x
     │ Char
─────┼──────
   1 │ d
   2 │ d```

elements.text:

First Group (4 rows): x = 'a'

     │ Char
─────┼──────
   1 │ a
   2 │ a
   3 │ a
   4 │ a
⋮
Last Group (2 rows): x = 'd'
 Row │ x
     │ Char
─────┼──────
   1 │ d
   2 │ d
